title: Boy, 9, charged with murdering three toddlers and two adults in house fire
text:
A nine year-old boy has been charged with murder after allegedly starting a fire that killed (L-R) Rose Alwood, Dameon Wall and Dameon’s sister Ariel Wall (Pictures: Legacy.com)

A nine year-old boy has been charged with murdering three toddlers and two adults after allegedly setting a mobile home on fire.

The youngster, who has not been named because of his age, was charged Tuesday over the April 6 blaze in Goodfield, Illinois.

That fire killed one year-old Ariel Wall, her brother Daemeon Wall and cousin Rose Alwood, who were both aged two.

Also killed were Ariel and Daemeon’s dad Jason Wall, 34, and the youngsters’ maternal great-grandma Kathryn Murray, 89.

All five died of smoke inhalation, with Jason Wall’s fiance Katrina Wall and her eight year-old son from a previous relationship managing to escape.

Also killed in the fire was Daemeon and Ariel’s great-grandma Kathryn Murray, 69, and her grandson Jason Wall (Pictures: Legacy.com)

Announcing the charges, prosecutor Greg Minger refused to reveal the alleged killer’s relationship to the victims.

He told the Journal Star that if convicted the boy will face five years probation, but will not be imprisoned, with any punishment set to conclude before the child turns 21.

The youngster’s case will be heard by a judge during a bench trial.

Minger said the decision to charge the boy was a ‘heavy’ one, adding: ‘It’s a tragedy, but at the end of the day it’s charging a very young person with one of the most serious crimes we have.

‘But I just think it needs to be done at this point, for finality.’

All five were killed in this April 2019 blaze at a mobile home in Goodfield, Illinois (Picture: Shawn Johnson)

Eyewitnesses told the Journal Star of how they heard screams coming from the trailer as it burned, but that the flames were too intense to try and save its occupants.

The boy was also charged with aggravated arson, over claims he knew there were people inside the mobile home when he allegedly set it alight.
description: The boy will not be jailed if he is convicted of starting the blaze in Goodfield, Illinois, but will spend up to five years on probation
